Trial_Design.evidence: An a priori power analysis showed that 112 participants were needed to detect a 15% difference in the likelihood of recommending surgery for white versus nonwhite patients in the test scenarios evaluated with 90% power at a level of significance of 0.05.

Participants.evidence: Orthopaedic surgeons attending the 2012 annual meetings of the New York State Society of Orthopaedic Surgeons and American Association of Hip and Knee Surgeons were recruited for the study.

Intervention.evidence: All participants viewed the “control” patient’s story (white male) and were randomized to view one of the three “experimental” scenarios (white female, black male, black female).

Objective.evidence: We sought to evaluate the effect of surgeon bias on recommendations for TKA.

Method_Outcome.evidence: After viewing each scenario, the participants were anonymously asked whether they would recommend TKA.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: All participants viewed the “control” patient’s story (white male) and were randomized to view one of the three “experimental” scenarios (white female, black male, black female).

Number_Randomised.evidence: Of the 1111 surgeons in attendance at either meeting, 113 (10.2%) participated in the study.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Of the 39 surgeons who viewed the white male plus black female scenario, there were 33 (85%) concordant responses.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Of the 39 surgeons who viewed the white male plus black female scenario, there were 33 (85%) concordant responses (TKA offered to both patients) and six discordant responses (TKA offered to only one of the patients), with no effect of patient race and sex (p = 0.99).
